locations.notes: UChicago years. Quick May trip to retrieve storage. Booth MBA 2026.
locations.extendedNotes: Four years at UChicago. Hyde Park bookstores, the Reg, Lake Michigan. Returning for Booth in 2026.

Architecture: Frank Lloyd Wright's Robie House in Hyde Park
The Loop's steel-frame skyscrapers invented the modern skyline
Chicago School of Architecture born from the 1871 fire rebuild
Hyde Park: Home to the University of Chicago since 1890
Seminary Co-op: one of the great academic bookstores
The City: Third largest US city, 2.7 million residents
77 distinct neighborhoods
Lake Michigan shoreline runs 26 miles through the city

locations.extendedNotes: Scouting trip for the 2026 Boston Marathon. Walked the final miles of the course from Heartbreak Hill to Boylston Street. Exploring the city's history and running culture.

The Marathon: 26.2 miles from Hopkinton to Boylston Street
Heartbreak Hill: mile 20-21, the famous climb
History: Founded 1630—one of America's oldest cities
Birthplace of the American Revolution
Home to Harvard (1636) and MIT
Culture: Freedom Trail: 2.5 miles of revolutionary history
Fenway Park: oldest MLB stadium (1912)
World-class hospitals and universities

locations.notes: Honolulu Marathon, Diamond Head sunrise hike, Lanikai Pillboxes, North Shore.
images: honolulu/Post marathon with Jenna sister - HNL 25.png
locations.extendedNotes: Honolulu Marathon with 5am start along Waikiki. Diamond Head crater hike at sunrise, Lanikai Pillboxes trail, North Shore beaches. Day trip to Maui via puddle jumper.

The Race: 5am start, ran into sunrise along Waikiki
Course: Ala Moana through Hawaii Kai
The Trip: Day trip to Maui via puddle jumper
The Island: Oahu: 600,000+ residents, most populated Hawaiian island
Diamond Head: volcanic crater, iconic silhouette

locations.notes: PR: 3:09. Flew in, raced, showered, flew out. Last Chance BQ.2.

The Race: Last Chance BQ.2: flat, fast Boston qualifier course
Fox River Trail: crushed limestone path
September timing for ideal running weather
The Town: Historic downtown on the Fox River
Known for antique shops and Swedish Days festival

locations.notes: Super Bowl weekend. College friends, pizza lines, rooftop views.
locations.extendedNotes: Super Bowl weekend trip in 2024 with college friends. Pizza lines, rooftop views of Manhattan skyline, walking across Brooklyn Bridge.

The City: 8.3 million residents, largest US city
Five boroughs: Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island
472 subway stations—largest in the Western Hemisphere
Culture: Broadway: 41 theaters in the Theater District
The Met: 2 million works spanning 5,000 years
MoMA: world's first museum dedicated to modern art
History: Originally New Amsterdam, Dutch colony founded 1626
Ellis Island processed 12 million immigrants (1892-1954)
Empire State Building: world's tallest 1931-1970

The City: 7x7 miles—one of the smallest major US cities
43 named hills, famous cable cars since 1873
The fog has a name: Karl
History: Gold Rush transformed it from 200 to 36,000 people (1848-1852)
1906 earthquake and fire destroyed 80% of the city
Summer of Love, 1967: birthplace of counterculture
Culture: Golden Gate Bridge: Art Deco, International Orange
Mission District: oldest neighborhood, murals everywhere
Third-wave coffee revolution started here

The City: Second largest US city, 4 million residents
503 square miles—you need a car
More museums per capita than any other US city
Hollywood: Film industry moved here 1910s for the sunlight
Culture: Venice Beach: Muscle Beach, boardwalk, street performers
Getty Center: free admission, stunning architecture
LACMA: Urban Light installation, 202 street lamps

locations.extendedNotes: Beach days in La Jolla and exploring the Gaslamp Quarter. Perfect weather for sunset walks along the coast.

The City: America's Finest City—70°F average year-round
70 miles of coastline and beaches
Birthplace of California (first European settlement, 1769)
Culture: San Diego Zoo: 3,700 animals, world-famous
Craft beer capital: 150+ breweries
Gaslamp Quarter: 16 blocks of Victorian architecture
History: Named by Spanish explorer Sebastián Vizcaíno, 1602
Major naval base since WWII
Border with Tijuana: busiest land crossing in the world

locations.extendedNotes: Quiet getaway to Georgia's Golden Isles. Private beaches and salt marshes at sunset.

The Island: Part of Georgia's Golden Isles barrier islands
History: G8 Summit hosted here in 2004
Originally a cotton plantation
Spanish explorers arrived in the 1500s

locations.extendedNotes: Home base for family visits. Deep Ellum murals, Dallas Arts District, and catching up with old friends.

The City: 9th largest US city, 1.3 million residents
No zoning laws—unique urban development
DFW Airport: world's 4th busiest
Culture: Deep Ellum: live music district since the 1920s jazz era
Dallas Arts District: largest urban arts district in the US
State Fair of Texas: Big Tex, Fletcher's corny dogs
History: Named for Vice President George M. Dallas, 1846
JFK assassination: Dealey Plaza, November 22, 1963
Oil boom transformed the city in the 1930s

Theme Parks: Walt Disney World opened 1971—twice the size of Manhattan
75 million tourists annually—most visited US destination
Universal, SeaWorld, LEGOLAND all within 30 miles
The City: Originally named Jernigan, renamed Orlando in 1857
More than 100 lakes within city limits
NASA's Kennedy Space Center 45 minutes east

locations.extendedNotes: Hiking trails through Mt. Rainier National Park with stunning alpine meadows. Pike Place Market exploring and ferry to Bainbridge Island.

The City: Surrounded by water, mountains, and evergreen forests
More coffee shops per capita than any US city
Rain reputation exaggerated: less annual rain than NYC
Culture: Pike Place Market: opened 1907, oldest farmers market in US
Birthplace of Starbucks (1971), Amazon, Microsoft
Grunge music scene: Nirvana, Pearl Jam, Soundgarden
Nature: Mt. Rainier: 14,411 ft, visible from the city on clear days
San Juan Islands: orcas, kayaking, ferries

locations.extendedNotes: Martin Luther King Jr. birthplace and the National Center for Civil and Human Rights. Piedmont Park for running, Krog Street Market for food halls.

History: Burned in Sherman's March to the Sea, 1864
Birthplace of Martin Luther King Jr.
Hosted the 1996 Summer Olympics
Culture: Birthplace of Coca-Cola (1886)
Hip-hop capital: OutKast, T.I., Migos, Lil Baby
CNN and Delta Air Lines headquarters

locations.notes: Art Deco, Little Havana, Wynwood murals.
locations.extendedNotes: Art Deco historic district on Ocean Drive. Little Havana for Cuban coffee, Wynwood Walls street art. Design District galleries.

Culture: 70% of residents speak Spanish at home
Little Havana: Cuban exile community since 1959
Art Basel Miami Beach every December
Architecture: Largest collection of Art Deco buildings in the world
South Beach historic district: 800+ preserved buildings
Designed for tropical living in the 1920s-30s
Neighborhoods: Wynwood—40+ acres of street art murals

locations.extendedNotes: Quiet summers on the Midcoast. Lobster shacks in Damariscotta, kayaking in South Bristol, and foggy morning walks.

The Coast: Acadia: first national park east of the Mississippi
Culture: Lobster capital: 80% of US lobster catch
Damariscotta: oyster middens 2,000+ years old
L.L. Bean flagship open 24/7/365 since 1951
History: Maine was part of Massachusetts until 1820
Wyeth family painted the Midcoast for generations
Shipbuilding heritage: Bath Iron Works since 1884

The City: Founded 1733—Georgia's first city
22 of original 24 squares remain
Largest National Historic Landmark District in the US
Culture: SCAD (Savannah College of Art and Design) transformed the city
Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil set here
Open container laws: walk the streets with a drink
History: Sherman spared Savannah in his March to the Sea
Spanish moss isn't Spanish or moss—it's a bromeliad
Forsyth Park fountain modeled after one in Paris

locations.notes: Four Seasons rooftop. Friend reunions, day trips from DC.
locations.extendedNotes: Four Seasons rooftop views of the city skyline. Walking through Old City and Rittenhouse Square. Easy day trips from DC for friend reunions.

History: US capital 1790-1800, before Washington DC
Declaration of Independence signed here, 1776
First US zoo, first hospital, first library
Culture: Philadelphia Museum of Art: Rocky Steps, 240,000 works
Mural Arts: 4,000+ murals—largest public art program in US
BYOB restaurant culture: no corkage fees
Neighborhoods: Old City: Independence Hall, Liberty Bell
Rittenhouse Square: urban park, upscale dining

locations.notes: First Japan trip. Shibuya Crossing, Meiji Shrine, Itoya Ginza stationery store.
locations.extendedNotes: Shibuya Crossing at night, morning walk through Meiji Shrine forest. Itoya Ginza 12-floor stationery flagship. Golden Gai bars, Tsukiji outer market.

The City: 37 million metro area—world's largest
Trains run on time to the second
Vending machines every 12 meters on average

locations.notes: Fushimi Inari torii gates at dawn. Arashiyama bamboo grove, Gion district.
locations.extendedNotes: Fushimi Inari shrine with 10,000 vermillion torii gates. Arashiyama bamboo grove and monkey park. Gion district evening walks. Day trips from Osaka base.

History: Imperial capital of Japan for 1,000 years (794-1868)
Spared from WWII bombing to preserve cultural heritage
2,000+ temples and shrines within the city
Culture: Gion: famous geisha district, preserved wooden machiya
Matcha tea ceremony originated in Kyoto temples
Traditional kaiseki cuisine refined here

locations.notes: Dotonbori neon signs at night. Base for Kyoto and Nara day trips.
locations.extendedNotes: Dotonbori at night with the Glico Running Man sign. Street food culture: takoyaki, okonomiyaki. Central base for day trips to Kyoto, Nara, and Hiroshima.

The City: Japan's second largest city, 2.7 million residents
Known as 'Japan's Kitchen' for street food culture
Osakans say 'kuidaore'—eat until you drop
Culture: Bunraku puppet theater originated here
More relaxed and humorous than Tokyo
Glico Running Man sign: Dotonbori landmark since 1935
History: Merchant city since the Edo period
Osaka Castle: rebuilt in 1931, original from 1583
Historically called 'the nation's kitchen'

locations.notes: Peace Memorial Park and A-Bomb Dome. Miyajima Island floating torii gate.

essay.title: Hiroshima
essay.excerpt: It's not enough to feel moved by history. You have a responsibility to live differently because of it.

locations.extendedNotes: Peace Memorial Museum and the A-Bomb Dome, the only structure left standing near the hypocenter. Day trip to Miyajima Island for the floating torii gate. This visit informed my Booth MBA application.

History: Atomic bomb dropped August 6, 1945, 8:15am
A-Bomb Dome: only structure left standing near hypocenter
City rebuilt as a symbol of peace
Peace Memorial: Peace Park designed by Kenzo Tange, 1954
Sadako's paper cranes: 1,000 for a wish
Flame will burn until all nuclear weapons are abolished
Miyajima: Floating torii gate: one of Japan's three great views
Sacred island: no births or deaths allowed historically

locations.notes: Best friend's wedding. Seine boat tour, Musee d'Orsay, the Marais.
locations.extendedNotes: Best friend's wedding in March. Seine boat tour, Musee d'Orsay Impressionists collection, the Marais neighborhood. Day trip to Chateau de Fontainebleau.

History: Founded by Celtic Parisii tribe, 3rd century BC
Haussmann redesigned the city 1853-1870
20 arrondissements spiral clockwise from center
Museums: Louvre: world's largest, 35,000 works on display
Musée d'Orsay: Impressionists in a former train station
Centre Pompidou: modern art, inside-out architecture
Culture: Café culture: the original third place
Over 400 parks and gardens in the city
Six train stations named after writers

locations.notes: V&A Museum, Hyde Park, West End shows, Paddington Station pilgrimage.
locations.extendedNotes: V&A decorative arts museum, Hyde Park walks, West End theater. London Eye at dusk. Walking between South Bank, Shoreditch, and Notting Hill.

History: Founded by Romans as Londinium, 43 AD
Great Fire of 1666 destroyed 80% of the city
The Tube opened 1863—world's first underground railway
Culture: West End: 40+ theaters, second only to Broadway
V&A: world's largest decorative arts museum
Pub culture: 3,500+ pubs in Greater London

Valencia: City of Arts and Sciences: futuristic Calatrava complex
Las Fallas festival: giant sculptures burned each March
Bilbao: Guggenheim Museum transformed the city in 1997
Basque country: distinct language, oldest in Europe
San Sebastián: More Michelin stars per capita than anywhere
La Concha: one of Europe's best urban beaches

locations.notes: Tepoztlan mountain town. Roma Norte neighborhood, Chapultepec Park runs.
locations.extendedNotes: Weekend escape to Tepoztlan mountain town with lush vegetation and ancient Aztec pyramid. Roma Norte neighborhood cafes, Chapultepec Park morning runs.

The City: Largest city in North America, 21+ million metro
Built on Lake Texcoco, sinking 4 inches per year
Aztec capital Tenochtitlan founded here in 1325
Culture: Frida Kahlo's Casa Azul in Coyoacán
Chapultepec: one of world's largest urban parks
Roma: film neighborhood, earthquake-scarred charm
History: Aztec capital Tenochtitlan founded 1325
Zócalo: one of the largest public plazas in the world
Palacio de Bellas Artes: Art Nouveau and Art Deco

locations.notes: TIFF festival visit. Toronto Islands, Kensington Market, St. Lawrence Market.
locations.extendedNotes: Toronto International Film Festival visit in September. Toronto Islands ferry, Kensington Market vintage shops, St. Lawrence Market for peameal bacon sandwiches.

The City: Most populous city in Canada (2.9 million)
Over 200 ethnicities—one of the most diverse cities globally
51% of residents born outside Canada
Culture: TIFF: Toronto International Film Festival each September
CN Tower: 553m, tallest free-standing structure 1975-2007
Hockey is religion: Maple Leafs haven't won since 1967

History: Founded in 1010 AD as Thang Long (Rising Dragon)
Continuous habitation for over 1,000 years
Renamed Hanoi (City Between Rivers) in 1831
Culture: Vietnamese coffee: egg coffee invented here in 1946
Pho originated in the early 20th century
36 streets of the Old Quarter—each named for a trade

Hue: Forbidden Purple City modeled on Beijing's
Perfume River runs through the citadel
Da Nang: Vietnam's third largest city, rising beach destination
Marble Mountains: five limestone peaks with caves and pagodas
My Son sanctuary: 4th-century Cham Hindu temples
History: DMZ (demilitarized zone) 100km north of Hue
Heavily bombed in Vietnam War, citadel rebuilt
Nguyen Dynasty tombs scattered along the Perfume River

The City: Full ceremonial name is 169 letters—world's longest
10+ million residents, one of Asia's largest cities
Never colonized—the only Southeast Asian country
Temples: Wat Phra Kaew: Temple of the Emerald Buddha
Wat Arun: Temple of Dawn, iconic Khmer-style spires
Over 400 Buddhist temples in the city
Culture: Street food capital—50,000+ vendors
Chatuchak Weekend Market: 15,000 stalls
Thai massage originated as temple medicine

The City: Financial capital of India, 20+ million metro area
Originally seven islands, joined by land reclamation
Renamed from Bombay in 1995
Culture: Bollywood: world's largest film industry by output
Dabbawalas: 5,000 deliverymen, 200,000 lunches daily
Local trains: 7.5 million passengers per day
Landmarks: Gateway of India: built 1924 for King George V visit
Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus: Victorian Gothic railway station

History: Eight cities built on this site over 3,000 years
New Delhi designed by Edwin Lutyens, 1911-1931
Red Fort: Mughal emperors ruled from here 1648-1857
Culture: Chandni Chowk: one of India's oldest markets (1650)
Jama Masjid: largest mosque in India
India Gate: memorial to 70,000 WWI soldiers
The City: Capital since 1911, 32+ million metro area
Metro system: 286 stations, one of world's largest
Three UNESCO World Heritage sites within city limits

locations.extendedNotes: Buddhist prayer wheels and stupas in Kathmandu. Sunrise over the Himalayas from Pokhara. Ancient temples and narrow streets of Bhaktapur.

Geography: 8 of the world's 10 highest peaks, including Everest
Culture: Birthplace of Buddha (Lumbini, 563 BC)
Only country with non-rectangular flag
Hindu and Buddhist traditions blend seamlessly
Kathmandu Valley: Three ancient royal cities: Kathmandu, Patan, Bhaktapur
Durbar Square: UNESCO World Heritage sites
Boudhanath: one of the largest stupas in the world

locations.extendedNotes: Traditional Sri Lankan wedding ceremonies with vibrant decorations. Exploring the streets of Colombo and coastal areas.

Culture: Ceylon tea: introduced by British in 1867
Sigiriya: ancient rock fortress, 5th century
Ayurvedic medicine tradition thousands of years old
Nature: Train through tea country: one of world's great rides
